arm_group.description: 160 Units of human insulin as nasal spray

brief_summary.textblock:
The researchers will investigate if brain insulin action influences peripheral insulin
      sensitivity in healthy humans.

clinical_study.brief_title: Influence of Brain Insulin Sensitivity on Peripheral Insulin Sensitivity

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  BMI < 28 kg/m2

          -  normal HbA1c

          -  healthy volunteers

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  Heparin induced thrombocytopenia (HIT)

          -  metal implants

          -  cardial diseases

          -  anemia

          -  patients taking any kind of drugs

facility.name: University of Tuebingen, Internal medicine IV

clinical_study.official_title: Influence of Brain Insulin Sensitivity on Peripheral Insulin Sensitivity

oversight_info.authority: Germany: Federal Institute for Drugs and Medical Devices

primary_outcome.description: We will measure insulin sensitivity by hyperinsulinemic euglycemic clamp before and after nasal spray application. We will compare the post-spray insulin sensitivity between the two condition (insulin nasal spray vs placebo nasal spray). Furthermore, we will compare insulin sensitivity before and after nasal insulin application.
primary_outcome.measure: Insulin sensitivity as measured by clamp
primary_outcome.time_frame: 45 minutes to 120 minutes post nasal spray

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

secondary_outcome.description: Activity of the autonomous nervous system will be estimated by heart rate variability in ECG. We will compare the post-spray autonomous nervous system activity between the two condition (insulin nasal spray vs placebo nasal spray). Furthermore, we will compare autonomous nervous system activity before and after nasal insulin application.

clinical_study.study_design: Allocation: Randomized, Intervention Model: Crossover Assignment, Masking: Single Blind (Subject), Primary Purpose: Basic Science
